title: 107_s381
content: The Act may be cited as the "Military Voting Support Act of 2001" and the table of contents is provided. The "Military Voting Support Act of 2001" includes provisions such as guaranteeing residency and voting rights for uniformed services members, using military buildings as polling places, and maximizing access to polls for recently separated voters. It also emphasizes the importance of voting by members of the uniformed services. The Senate emphasizes the importance of uniformed services voters' right to vote and urges election administrators to ensure these voters receive cooperation and have their valid ballots counted. The Uniformed and Overseas Citizens Absentee Voting Act is amended to set standards for the invalidation of certain ballots, stating that a State cannot reject a ballot from an absent uniformed services voter unless clear and convincing evidence of fraud is found. The amendments to the Uniformed and Overseas Citizens Absentee Voting Act establish standards for rejecting ballots from absent uniformed services voters, requiring clear and convincing evidence of fraud. The amendments do not affect state ballot submission deadlines. The effective date applies to ballots submitted after the enactment of the Act. The Guarantee of Residency and Voting Rights is established in Section 4. The Soldiers' and Sailors' Civil Relief Act of 1940 is amended to guarantee residency for military personnel voting in federal or state elections, regardless of their absence due to military orders. The Soldiers' and Sailors' Civil Relief Act of 1940 is amended to ensure voting rights for military personnel in federal or state elections. States are required to allow absentee voting for uniformed services voters in all elections and process their registration applications received at least 30 days before the election. The Soldiers' and Sailors' Civil Relief Act of 1940 is amended to ensure voting rights for military personnel in federal or state elections by requiring states to allow absentee voting for uniformed services voters and process their registration applications at least 30 days before the election. The heading of title I of the Uniformed and Overseas Absentee Voting Act is amended. Title I of the Uniformed and Overseas Absentee Voting Act is amended to allow the use of military installations and reserve component facilities as polling places. The Uniformed and Overseas Absentee Voting Act is amended to allow military installations to be used as polling places for Federal, State, or local elections. The Secretary of a military department can make a building on a military installation available for this purpose, and once designated, it must continue to be used as a polling place. The Secretary of a military department can designate a military installation as a polling place for elections, and must provide advance notice to Congress if the site will no longer be used for this purpose. Additionally, Reserve Component Facilities can also be used as polling places under certain conditions. The Secretary of a military department can designate a military installation as a polling place for elections, and must provide advance notice to Congress if the site will no longer be used for this purpose. States are permitted to use facilities for polling places in elections despite certain legal restrictions. The amendments to Title 18 allow military installations and reserve component facilities to be used as polling places in elections without being considered interference by armed forces. The amendments to Title 18 allow military installations and reserve component facilities to be used as polling places in elections in accordance with specific sections of Title 10. The beginning of chapter 159 of Title 18 is amended. SEC. 6. MAXIMIZING THE ACCESS OF RECENTLY SEPARATED UNIFORMED SERVICES VOTERS TO THE POLLS. SEC. 6. MAXIMIZING THE ACCESS OF RECENTLY SEPARATED UNIFORMED SERVICES VOTERS TO THE POLLS. In General, each State must treat recently separated uniformed services voters as residents, waive residency requirements, accept voter registration applications on election day, and allow them to vote in any election. The term "State" refers to a State of the United States, the District of Columbia, Puerto Rico, or a U.S. territory. A "recently separated uniformed services voter" is someone who was a uniformed services voter 60 days before seeking to vote, no longer holds that status, and is qualified to vote. SEC. 7. UNIFORMED SERVICES ELECTRONIC VOTING DEMONSTRATION PROJECT. In this section, key definitions are provided including "Federal office," "Secretary," "Uniformed services," and "Uniformed services voter" which encompass various branches of the military and related personnel. The Absentee Voting Act allows for electronic voting systems for uniformed services voters during federal elections. A demonstration project will be conducted in 2002 to assess feasibility, with a report due to Congress by June 1, 2003. Authorization of appropriations is provided for this purpose. Governors are required to report on the implementation of federal voting assistance program recommendations. In this section, definitions for "legislative recommendation" and "Presidential designee" are provided. A legislative recommendation is a suggestion for modifying state laws to enhance access to polls for absent uniformed services voters and overseas voters. The Presidential designee refers to the head of the executive department designated under the Uniformed and Overseas Citizens Absentee Voting Act. States must submit reports within 90 days of receiving a legislative recommendation. The State must submit a report on the status of implementing a legislative recommendation to the Presidential designee and each Member of Congress representing the State. The reporting period starts from the enactment of the Act and lasts for 3 years.
